ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TOWN COUNCILS
(Success in shaping social behaviour and attitude)


    1. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for National Development since the setting up of town councils to manage public housing estates and give residents the kind of environment they prefer, (a) to what extent have the social behaviour and attitude of residents been shaped by the town councils; and (b) has there been any survey done to assess the town councils' success in shaping such behaviour and attitude.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, Town Councils were formed with two key objectives: firstly, to devolve the responsibility for estate management from HDB to local councils and, secondly, to allow participation by residents in decision-making on local estate management matters. These objectives have been met. This is evident in the many improvements made by Town Councils to the common property and the transformation of HDB housing estates into vibrant communities.

    In the initial years, Town Councils focused on the hardware aspect of estate management. Their role has evolved over the years to include the promotion of social responsibility and community bonding amongst residents, through close collaboration with the Community Development Councils and other grassroots organisations. The Annual Island-Wide Cleanest Estate Competition and Annual Town Days are some examples of such collaborative efforts.

    The focus of our surveys in the past has been on how satisfied residents are with the maintenance of their estates and the quality of the services provided by the Town Councils. These results have been positive so far. For example, in a survey

Column: 2279

conducted in 2000, 96.2% of the respondents gave a "very clean or clean" rating to their towns, as compared to only 67.1% in 1996. Secondly, as far as enforcement actions by Town Councils are concerned, 88% of the respondents gave a "very effective or effective" rating as compared to only 78.5% in the 1996 survey.

    It may be more meaningful for Town Councils to conduct specific surveys to assess their own efforts at the local level in shaping social behaviour and attitude, so that they can tailor their programmes accordingly. Several Town Councils, for example, Marine Parade, East Coast and Bishan-Toa Payoh, have in fact taken the initiative to conduct surveys on their own performance. We would like to encourage other Town Councils to follow their lead.

Column: 2279

SINGAPORE AND SHANGHAI
(Comparison as a vibrant city)


    2. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how is Singapore compared with Shanghai as a vibrant city with a lot of "buzz" which is good for business, and (b) how do we create and maintain such vibrancy in Singapore.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, I interpret Mrs Yu-Foo's question to be about the competition between Singapore and Shanghai.

    If China continues on its path of economic growth, Shanghai will be one of the world's greatest cities in the coming decades. In many ways, it will reclaim its pre-eminent position in Asia, which was its status in the 1930s.

    The `buzz' in Shanghai is the result of the sheer concentration of human talent there. Even before Deng Xiaoping's reform and opening up of the Chinese economy, Shanghai contributed disproportionately to China's economic, scientific, political, intellectual and cultural life. Once China opened up, Shanghai's natural

Column: 2280

vitality expressed itself, helped by a very competent municipal leadership.

    I believe Mrs Yu-Foo worries whether Shanghai is a competitive threat to Singapore. Well, in some sectors, we compete as we do with other cities. But, overall, no. Shanghai's growth and prosperity will help to raise the entire region.

    In Hong Kong, the people there worry a lot about Shanghai because the two cities are geographically not very far apart. And after 1997, there is a feeling among Hong Kongers that Shanghai is the eldest son on whom Beijing will shower the greatest favour. For this reason, Chinese leaders take great pains to assure the people of Hong Kong that they will be looked after.

    As for Singapore, we are actually quite far away from Shanghai. It takes almost five hours to fly there which is about the same time it takes to fly from London to Jerusalem or from Washington to Los Angeles. Although China and Southeast Asia compete for FDI, Singapore's relationship with Shanghai is largely cooperative and complementary. For this reason, we have been building up our presence in Shanghai and around Shanghai over the years. One reason why we are at Suzhou is because of its proximity to Shanghai.

    How do we increase the `buzz' in Singapore? That really is the objective of the ERC and our other efforts to remake Singapore. The key is our economy. To stay competitive, we must keep taxes low, improve our infrastructure, simplify our regulations, educate our people, train and retrain ourselves continuously, bring in international talent, protect property, including intellectual property, and develop broadband economic connectivity with our Southeast Asian neighbours and with the US, Europe, Japan, China, India and Australia. And that is the reason why we are now embarking on so many FTAs. Being an independent city-state, we will always be more cosmopolitan and outward-looking than any other city in Asia, including Shanghai. This cosmopolitan spirit must also be expressed in our intellectual and cultural

Column: 2281

life. Our promotion of the arts is an essential part of this.

    Shanghai is the economic, intellectual and cultural centre of China. We must ensure that we keep our place as one of the key economic, intellectual and cultural centres in Southeast Asia. Provided we do that, Singapore will be useful to Shanghai, as Shanghai is useful to Singapore.

BOOSTER SEAT REQUIREMENT FOR ADULTS
(Rationale)


    3. Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what is the rationale for enforcing a booster seat requirement for adults below 1.5 metres in height as part of the seat belt rule; and (b) whether his Ministry has ensured that the market is able to supply the booster seats.

    The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, it is a misconception that adults below the height of 1.5 metres must use a booster seat. The correct position is this. Persons who are eight years or older but who are below the height of 1.5 metres are, in fact, exempted from having to belt up. It is unsafe for any person below 1.5 metres in height to wear a body restraining seat belt in a vehicle as the shoulder part of the belt would be placed against the person's neck instead of lying over the shoulder. In the event of an accident, the seat belt may strangle him or her. However, parents of children above eight years old and young teenagers who are below 1.5 metres in height, are encouraged to use booster seats to elevate the seating position of their children so that the seat belts may be strapped safely across the shoulder. For the same reason, adults below 1.5 metre in height are also encouraged to use booster seats so that they may strap up safely.

    However, children below the age of eight years must be properly secured by an approved child restraint. This has been the requirement since 1993. Many parents who were concerned for the safety of

Column: 2282

their children had already purchased the child restraints. However, there were many others who started looking around for a child restraint only after Police announced that they would tighten enforcement action against those who flout the rule.

    Traffic Police had anticipated the likely increase in demand for child restraints. In May this year, it had advised major retailers to keep sufficient stocks.

    Traffic Police is monitoring the stock levels at major retail outlets. Child restraints are temporarily out of stock while booster seats are still available in the market. New supplies are expected in a week's time. In the meantime, Traffic Police will continue to advise motorists of the safety measures required for young passengers.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I would like to confirm once again that for a child above eight years old, it is not compulsory for the child to use a booster seat or a car seat. Is that true?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Provided he is a short child. If he is below 1.5 metres in height, then he is not required to use a booster seat or a child seat. The position is this. A child who is below eight years old must use a child restraint. A child who is above eight years old, but who is below 1.5 metres, need not use a child restraint nor a booster seat, although he is encouraged to do so.

LINKS ISLAND SHARES
(Assistance to affected investors)


    4. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what avenues of help are available for investors, who are caught by the Singapore Exchange Settlement Committee's decision on the Links Island shares and who are forced to pick up the trades that they have sold per contra before the suspension; and (b) whether there is a fund to help such affected investors and to prevent the broking firms from taking legal action against them.

Column: 2283



    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, before the Minister replies, I would like to again declare my interest as regards Question No. 4.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, in July last year, SGX announced that its investigations had revealed that a corner situation had arisen in Links shares. In accordance with the SGX Rules, the SGX Settlement Committee decided that all outstanding market trades in Links shares done during 14-16th August 2000 be settled by way of cash instead of delivery, at the fair settlement price of $1.21. This ruling also applied to sale transactions by contra traders who had bought Links shares before 14th August 2000 and sold those shares during 14-16th August 2000. As a result, such contra traders had to pick up and pay for the shares they bought because their sale transactions, like all other market trades during the period, had been settled in cash instead of by delivery.

    Some brokers have indicated to SGX that they are prepared to extend credit to help ease any cashflow difficulties faced by such investors. Others have allowed their clients to pay for the shares by instalments. MAS encourages such flexibility on the part of the brokers, so long as they comply with regulatory requirements. MAS cannot, however, require or compel all brokers to do so.

    Another proposal was for SGX to use its fidelity fund to help the affected investors. This is not legally possible as the Securities Industry Act stipulates that the fund may be used only to compensate investors in the event of defalcation by a broker or to pay creditors when a broker winds up.

    SGX has informed the company that it is prepared to allow Links shares to resume trading provided the company puts in place safeguards to prevent the counter from being cornered again. One of the safeguards that the parties are

Column: 2284

discussing is for the company to restore its free float to an appropriate level. The company's free float had fallen to less than 8% (below the minimum 10% required by SGX Rules) at the time of Links' trading suspension in August 2000. If the company can meet SGX's requirements and trading in Links shares resumes, contra traders with Links shares will have the opportunity to sell their Links shares. But there is no guarantee that they will be able to sell their Links shares at the prices prevailing before the trading suspension.

    A contra trader should always be prepared to fork out the full amount for his share purchases and not rely on the proceeds from subsequent sale to pay for them. Apart from a corner situation where the SGX Rules provide for cash settlement of outstanding market trades at fair settlement price, there are other risks that contra investors should take into account before engaging in contra transactions. For instance, if trading in the counter should be suspended for a few days (either by the listed company or SGX as provided for under the SGX Rules), before the investor could contra his outstanding purchases, he would have to pay for the shares in full. Or if the share price fell sharply after the investor had bought his shares, he would have to sell off the shares at a loss if he could not pay for them. Therefore, it is not prudent for an investor to over-stretch himself by relying on contra trades to pay for his share purchases.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, regarding contra trades, the trades were actually done within the three days and the client would have assumed that they had already been settled. But it was suspended, and after one year the Stock Exchange came and said that the trades were actually nullified under the settlement process. So it was not that the contra traders did not prepare for it. They actually prepared for it but the market had fallen in the one year and whatever savings they had to buy the shares had already been depleted by the market. My question to the Minister is that, in the last three days of trading, the

Column: 2285

stock prices would actually have gone up, implying that the syndicates had bought more shares to corner the company. So if the Stock Exchange had nullified the trading by requiring that it be settled in cash, would it not be giving the syndicates an easy escape route?

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are ways to deal with a corner situation. This is a problem which can arise in any stock market, and there are established ways to deal with it. There is no totally satisfactory way because, by definition, in a corner situation, there are not enough shares to go around. People have committed to deliver more shares than are available because people have shorted, and now they cannot get hold of shares for delivery.

    It is like playing musical chairs - ten people running around, nine chairs to sit upon, and the music has stopped. Now, you say, "I am going to sit in this chair", or "I have already "choped" this chair. Therefore, let me do that, and let everybody else settle on their own." But you cannot do that because you may have "choped" this, somebody else may say, "Well, I am waiting for you to do this to settle, and there is a chance I can settle in scrip too." So finally, the most equitable arrangement which is fair both to the people who are long in the shares and who are short in the shares is to say, "There are not enough to go around, we will establish a fair price that the committee sets. They decide what the amount is and, at that price, we settle in cash." And later on, if the shares trade again, at that point, you buy and sell the shares for whatever they are worth. Now, the music has stopped, we settle in cash at a price which is fair to both who are long and who are short.

    The duration of the suspension was not something which the Stock Exchange wanted to do. It was something which was unavoidable given the complexities of the investigation into the case because, in this case, many shareholders were involved and the Stock Exchange and CAD had to investigate the relationship between

Column: 2286

them to establish whether or not they were acting in concert, and whether or not a corner situation existed. So they took one whole year to establish this. And finally, they declared that the corner situation existed, not because they were sitting around, but because investigations were complicated.

    The risk of this happening is always there. When you enter into a contra trade, you hope that you would not have to pay in full for the shares which you have already bought, and that you can sell them off and contra it. But between the buying and the contra, several days pass and things can happen in between which can frustrate that matching. And in this case, something did happen. The Stock Exchange acted according to its rules which are published. So before you enter into a contra trade, everybody must know that there is a risk of the stock being suspended, and especially in the case of Links Island, where the prices had been going up, all the more, anybody who goes in knows that this is a speculative punt, and you are taking a risk. So I think that the Stock Exchange did the right thing.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: May I clarify with the Minister? Is it not more equitable to require all trades, whether before the suspension or during the three days of trading, to be dealt through the normal settlement process? That means, those who have bought and sold accordingly are due, whether they sold the shares, they have to get them delivered, or if they have bought, they have to pay, rather than having a retrospective step of removing the three days and say that all trades done during that particular three days be nullified. Is it not equitable in that sense?

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are on a T-plus-3 settlement. So those are trades which have not been closed, which are still open. At the point of suspension, these are trades which are left hanging and you have to find some ways to settle it. As I explained, you cannot settle in stock. Therefore, some price has to be established and, in this

Column: 2287

case, the committee established a fair market price.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Can I clarify with the Minister again? Why did SGX take the three days? Why did it not take T-plus-4, the four days trade, or the two days' trade, or just on Wednesday itself, instead of having the three days' trade?

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not sure whether the question is why are we averaging over three days, or why are we nullifying the trades over three days. If you ask why we are nullifying over three days, the answer is because those were the trades which were not closed, they had not settled, because we are on a T-plus-3 settlement. So any time, when you intervene, you have three days' worth of transaction which you have to clean up. As for the price, what is a fair price? It is for the committee to decide. They deliberated and they decided that they would average over three days.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, if I may clarify further that it is actually T-plus-3. So it is four days of trade, and not three days. Effectively, the Stock Exchange is only using three days which is, if the stock is bought on Friday, it is still not closed for that matter. I think the Stock Exchange has not used the correct calculation, when they used only three days. They should have used four days instead.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: That is a different issue which the Member is raising. His first question was why not allow people who have stock to settle in stock, and I have explained that. Now he is asking whether we can go on four days, instead of three. These are technical issues which I will leave to the Stock Exchange to settle.

ODD LOT TRADING MARKET AND MAIN MARKET
(Merger)


    5. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) if there are plans to merge

Column: 2288

the odd lot trading market with the main board in the Singapore Exchange; (b) if there are, when; and (c) if there are none, will the Minister enlighten the House and the investing public the rationale for continuing to keep the odd lot market separate.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, SGX does not currently have any plans to merge the odd lot trading market with the main market.

    Currently, SGX sets a minimum board lot size for every company listed on the Exchange. The usual board lot size is 1,000 shares, although smaller board lot sizes are normally allowed for counters with a share price of more than $10. In the case of SingTel, board lots of 10 shares and 100 shares have been provided so that Singaporeans who received shares during SingTel's initial public offer in 1993 can trade those shares and the resulting bonus shares easily.

    Standardised board lots facilitate trading among investors. Otherwise, it would be difficult to match buyers and sellers of odd numbers of shares. SGX has received feedback that abolishing minimum board lots could increase the cost of trading as investors may then have to enter into multiple transactions to effect a single sale or purchase.

    Further, abolishing minimum board lots could result in listed companies having large numbers of shareholders each holding a small number of shares. This could increase the cost of shareholder communication (eg, printing and sending annual reports and shareholder circulars) for our listed companies significantly.

    Other major exchanges, such as the New York Stock Exchange and NASDAQ, also prescribe minimum board lots.

    Given that a large number of our listed companies trade at less than $1.00 per share, the usual board lot size of 1,000 shares is not likely to prevent the

Column: 2289

investing public from participating in the stock market.

    Nevertheless, SGX recognises that investors may sometimes receive odd lots, for example, as a result of a bonus issue, or rights issue, by the listed company. To enable investors to trade their odd lots, SGX provides an odd lot market. Currently, the odd lot market lacks liquidity because it is difficult to find an exact match between buyers and sellers of odd numbers of shares. This is unlike the odd lot markets on New York Stock Exhange and NASDAQ where there are market makers and specialists who stand ready to buy up odd lots to form round lots for subsequent sale. Further, the introduction of a minimum commission of $30 has made trading of odd lots of small numbers of shares uneconomical. SGX is currently holding discussions with industry practitioners with a view to overcoming these difficulties.

FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE SCHEME
(Review of income criterion)


    6. Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked the Minister for Education (a) whether his Ministry will review the income criterion for application of the Ministry's Financial Assistance Scheme (FAS) including the FAS for Independent Schools; and (b) how many schools have their own FAS with different eligibility criteria.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the income criteria for the Ministry of Education's Financial Assistance Scheme is pegged to the MCDS' Public Assistance Scheme. When MCDS revises the Public Assistance criteria, MOE will also review the criteria for its Financial Assistance Scheme for Government and Government-aided schools. The Financial Assistance Scheme for Independent schools will also be included in this review.

    Besides the Ministry's Financial Assistance Scheme, all schools - Government, Government-aided and Indepen-

Column: 2290

dent - also administer their own financial assistance schemes through their School Advisory Committees (SACs) or School Management Committees (SMCs). Individual Advisory or Management Committees set their own eligibility criteria according to the requirements of their students. In addition, our CDCs, CCCs, other community groups and Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs) also have their own assistance schemes for school going children and their families.

    No child is denied an education because of financial difficulties. Our schools will help all those who need financial assistance. Parents should approach the principals should they encounter any difficulties in their school fees.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied): Sir, when was the scheme last reviewed? Would the Ministry not consider that $800 is actually too low particularly for families who have more children or ageing parents to support? Definitely, we should consider using per capita family income instead. And would the Ministry consider making available the list of those schools with additional Financial Assistance Scheme for all the MPs so that they can better serve and help their residents who need this scheme?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the scheme was revised in April last year. When MCDS revises its criteria, we will do accordingly. This scheme is not the only way in which we are assisting pupils. To begin with, schooling in Singapore is almost completely subsidised. The cost recovery rates are very low. I mentioned the range of schemes available through the community, and through all the schools. We also have the Edusave Merit Bursary which is for pupils doing well and who fall below a certain income band. That covers quite a broad percentage of our students. If there is any student, or family, who still faces difficulty, they can approach their MP who, I am sure, will be quite willing to see how he can be assisted.

STATUTORY CORPORATIONS (CAPITAL CONTRIBUTION) BILL



    Order for Second Reading read.
12.55 pm

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Bill before the House seeks to amend the Financial Procedure Act and various other written laws to enable the Government to fund statutory boards through the injection of capital, instead of being restricted to funding them only through grants. The injection will be made out of capital contributions appropriated by Parliament.

Rationale

    Currently, statutory corporations are given direct capital grants, funded out of Government revenue to finance their development projects. They are not charged for the capital provided to them. As a result of this "free" endowment of capital, some agencies might not fully economise on the use of capital or make effective choices between capital and other financial resources. The best way to bring about proper accountability for the use of capital is to introduce a debt-equity financing structure in statutory corporations as in the case of companies. This Bill will help to bring about such a market-based financing structure by making it possible for all statutory corporations to receive "equity" or capital injection from the Government.

    Besides capital injection, statutory corporations should also be allowed to more freely take up debt financing options, such as loans and bonds. This funding approach is also in line with the recommendation by the ERP Sub-committee on Policies Related to Taxation, CPF System, Wages and Land, for the Government to use the capital markets more extensively to finance bankable projects.

Column: 2292



    Capital grants to statutory corporations are currently given in the form of a single upfront cash outlay. This results in lumpy Government spending. With the new funding framework, payment for capital assets would be spread out as annual operating subventions over the useful life of the assets. This is no different from the Government renting or leasing the asset. It gives a proper matching between the use of the assets and the costing of services.
